image.altText: Corporal Alex Naggs (left), Lieutenant Maxwell Nugent (middle) and Warrant Officer Class 2 Joseph Laycock.

items.synopsis: Finding the four missing crewmen, feared dead, is the main focus of the search and investigation, Minister for Defence Personnel Matt Keogh says after the MRH90 Taipan crashed into the ocean last week.

title.children: Air investigators arrive at scene of Army chopper crash in north Queensland

image.altText: Two women in an office look at a laptop.

items.synopsis: A surge in sales of homes purchased within the past two or three years has analysts and agents concerned the property market is rolling over as mortgage stress bites.

title.children: 'We need to sell': Why Australians are ditching homes they bought just a couple of years ago

image.altText: MCU of Wally Lewis wearing dark suit, white shirt and purple tie

items.synopsis: Wally Lewis reveals he has been diagnosed with probable chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) – describing his shock after seeing scans of brain that even made his doctor tear up.

title.children: Rugby League legend Wally Lewis diagnosed with probable CTE

image.altText: Margo Wiltens stands on a beach vollyball court and stands ready to spike a ball.

items.synopsis: "We need women and young girls to see female coaches, to believe that they too can achieve positions of responsibility and influence."

title.children: Paris 2024 will be first Olympics to achieve gender parity among athletes, but there's still a long way to go

image.altText: A mobile speed camera to be used by Queensland Police Service over the 2016 Christmas/New Year's period

items.synopsis: The State Penalties Enforcement Registry has written off more than $100 million in unpaid fines for the second year in a row, but it has also boosted its collections to a record high.

title.children: Queensland government debt collector wipes another $100 million in unpaid fines

image.altText: A Centrelink sign with on a building with a reflection

items.synopsis: The opposition says it will attempt to amend the government's measure to raise the Jobseeker rate by $40, and instead lift the threshold before benefits begin to be reduced, saying it would encourage more people into work.

title.children: Coalition moves to reverse $40 JobSeeker lift, proposing lift to benefits cut-off instead

image.altText: David Warner squints as he plays a cross bat shot that sends the ball into the air

items.synopsis: A period of brilliant batting and some timely rain gives Australia hope of achieving something remarkable on the last day of this Ashes series, and David Warner is central to the drama.

title.children: As defiant as ever, David Warner earns the chance to become Australia's Ashes hero

image.altText: Book of legislation partly opened

items.synopsis: Queensland’s powerful rental regulator is accused of going soft on law-breaking landlords and letting down tenants — who it is designed to protect.

title.children: Queensland's rental authority has not prosecuted a landlord or agent for more than two years

image.altText: A smiling mother sits in her kitchen and holds her baby.

items.synopsis: A new survey involving hundreds of Australian parents finds workplaces aren't communicating with staff while on parental leave, and are changing their jobs without consultation.

title.children: Ali was offered redundancy each time after having children. Research shows this is common

image.altText: A middle-aged woman with blonde hair, sunglasses and a dark cap smiles holding a box of keepcups labelled 'walking cups'.

items.synopsis: There isn't a whole lot of consistency in Australia around what single-use plastics are being phased out and when. See what's happening in your state.

title.children: Single-use plastic coffee cups are being banned in some states. What's happening where you live?

image.altText: Matildas star Sam Kerr frowns as she talks with a team coachduring a training session.

items.synopsis: A decision on whether superstar Sam Kerr can play in the Matildas' must-win Women's World Cup game against Canada will be a late call, according to coach Tony Gustavsson.

title.children: Availability of Kerr to 'go down to the wire', Matildas coach says, admitting missing out on knockout stages would be a 'failure'

image.altText: A shiny white and grey kitchen countertop.

items.synopsis: The reality is these shiny stone benchtops are not a necessity and too many of our tradies who work with them are getting sick or dying, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Kitchen benches are still killing young tradies — and we know how to stop it

image.altText: A large phone tower stands on dusty earth before a blue sky

items.synopsis: A prominent Pilbara pastoralist calls for a "gesture of goodwill" from Fortescue Metals Group after it switched off a remote phone tower in the middle of a mobile black spot.

title.children: Anger at Andrew Forrest's mining company's decision to switch off mobile coverage

image.altText: Two photos side-by-side of a crashed light plane upside down on grass

items.synopsis: The horse involved in Sunday's light plane crash on South Australia's Yorke Peninsula has been put down, police say.

title.children: Horse hit by plane during attempted take-off in regional SA dies

image.altText: A man in a navy blue suit.

items.synopsis: The inquiry, which began in mid-April, was sparked by a letter from the ACT's top prosecutor, claiming police pressured him not to charge Mr Lehrmann and alleging political interference.

title.children: Inquiry's report into prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann to be handed to government today

image.altText: A mother and her two young sons.

items.synopsis: At just five years of age, Lachie Draper-Shaw began caring for his mother and younger brother, missing out on his first year of school. But more support is now on offer.

title.children: 'It just felt normal': Lachie has been a carer since he was five, and he is not alone

image.altText: A Whole New Ballgame | David Pocock

items.synopsis: Independent senator David Pocock says the federal government should be given a duty of care to protect young people from climate change when assessing fossil fuel projects.

title.children: Independent senator David Pocock to propose climate impacts 'duty of care' law

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market begins its day higher ahead of tomorrow's Reserve Bank decision, which is widely expected to be a "pause" in its interest-rate-hiking cycle. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rises as markets bet on RBA pausing interest rate hikes

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The likelihood of whether the Reserve Bank will lift interest rates or not at its next meeting (August 1) has fluctuated wildly in the past few weeks. The ASX's RBA Rate Indicator shows, on July 21, the odds of a rate hike surged to 48% after the Bureau of Statistics revealed the unemployment rate remained steady at 3.5% (near its lowest level in 50 years). Five days later, the probability fell to 14% when the ABS announced that inflation fell at quicker-than-expected pace in the June quarter. The odds continued to fall on Friday (down to 8% ), after the latest retail sales figures came in worse-than-expected:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Markets pricing in 8% chance of Reserve Bank rate hike, according to ASX indictator

at its next meeting (August 1) has fluctuated wildly in the past few weeks.
The
ASX's RBA Rate Indicator
shows, on July 21, the odds of a rate hike surged to 48% after the Bureau of Statistics revealed the unemployment rate remained steady at 3.5% (near its lowest level in 50 years).
Five days later, the probability fell to 14% when the ABS announced that
inflation
fell at quicker-than-expected pace in the June quarter.
The odds continued to fall on Friday (down to
), after the latest

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! I'll be here to guide you through the latest business and economic news. The local share market is likely to open higher, with ASX futures suggesting a 0.3% rise in morning trade. It comes after a strong finish on Wall Street last Friday (US time), which saw the Dow Jones, S & P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rise 0.5%, 1% and 1.9% respectively. In economic news, the key event is tomorrow's Reserve Bank board meeting. Markets are betting the likelihood of of an interest rate hike is around 20%, according to Refinitiv data. However, economists from Westpac, Commonwealth Bank and other places are predicting the RBA will (more likely than not) lift its cash rate target. If the RBA keeps rates on hold, it would mean the cash rate remains at a decade high of 4.1% .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to rise ahead of tomorrow's RBA decision

image.altText: Seen through glass, a woman looks annoyed with raised hand, facing another person, visible from behind.

items.synopsis: More than simply being annoying, difficult people can impact your psychological safety, argues expert Rebecca Ray. But their power can be diminished.

title.children: Difficult people make you 'psychologically unsafe'. Here's how to recognise them

image.altText: A woman wearing a long, purple gown on the red carpet

items.synopsis: Sonia Kruger takes home the most prestigious award in Australian television, winning the 2023 Gold Logie in Sydney on Sunday.

title.children: 'I cannot believe that, I have to compose myself': Sonia Kruger shocked to win 2023 Gold Logie

image.altText: young girl holding horse with her arm up

items.synopsis: An endurance ride that attracted the likes of cattleman RM Williams during the 1980s is back. While some things have changed, the Winton to Longreach Endurance Ride is still a show of strength, grit, and horsemanship.

title.children: Revival of tough endurance ride creates new generation of outback 'legends'

image.altText: Close up photo of Indigenous man smiling in front of microphone.

items.synopsis: Malcolm Walalgie, who lives with cerebral palsy, loves life in his WA town. But he says "people like me" can't enjoy every aspect of it — and that is something he wants changed.

title.children: This busker knows the streets well, including where he can and can't go

image.altText: Fire and smoke from bonfire containing guitars and musical equipment

items.synopsis: Taliban authorities destroy dozens of instruments and equipment, saying music "causes moral corruption and playing it will cause the youth to go astray".

title.children: Taliban officials burn dozens of musical instruments

items.synopsis: Squawks, creaky doors, trills, bellows and a lot of grunts — our wildlife makes some bizarre and beguiling noises. But which one should get the shout-out as Australia's favourite animal sound? It's time to make a call.

title.children: From kookaburra cackles to the bonk of the banjo frog: Only one can be crowned Australia's favourite animal sound

image.altText: A composite image of a woman and a man holding awards in their hands

items.synopsis: The 2023 Logie Awards saw some rather unexpected wins and heartfelt tributes. These were the biggest moments of the night.

title.children: Sonia Kruger wins gold and tributes flow for Jock Zonfrillo: The biggest 2023 Logie Awards moments

image.altText: Man in blue shirt stands in front of burning door

items.synopsis: Images show demonstrators burning French flags and embassy doors as surrounding nations threaten sanctions amid Niger coup.

title.children: African nations threaten force as Niger protests against coup intervention

image.altText: A heavily built, unsmiling man wearing a suit and tie.

items.synopsis: Italy made an "improvised and atrocious" decision when it joined China's Belt and Road Initiative four years ago as it did little to boost exports, Italian Defence Minister Guido Crosetto says in an interview.

title.children: Italy's defence minister says joining China's Belt and Road initiative was 'atrocious' decision

image.altText: Woman lifting the lid of a funeral urn.

items.synopsis: From firing them into the night sky, to letting fly at the SCG, to tossing them at Pink, people are finding creative ways to scatter ashes — but what are the do's and don'ts when it comes to farewelling your loved one's remains?

title.children: Scattering ashes of a loved one? Read this before giving the final send-off

image.altText: The moment a Ukrainian drone hit a building in Moscow.

items.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says that "war is returning to the territory of Russia" after two drones crashed into Moscow's city business district.

title.children: Zelenskyy says 'war returning to the territory of Russia' after overnight drone attack on Moscow

image.altText: An orange car is full of happy people, one is holding a fish in the air. The car is on the beach and it is dark.

items.synopsis: A rag-tag team of engineers, commercial divers and rev-heads have driven 7km under water across the Darwin Harbour, in a stunt they claim has broken two world records.

title.children: Team drives 7km under water across Darwin Harbour, but takes five hours longer than expected
